case_vignette: A 2-hours-old neonate is found to have bluish discoloration throughout his body, including lips and tongue. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery with no prenatal care. Maternal history is positive for type 2 diabetes mellitus for 11 years. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 55/33 mm Hg, his heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 45/min, temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. Appropriate measures are taken. Auscultation of the chest reveals a single second heart sound without murmurs. Chest X-ray is shown in the exhibit.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby's body, including his lips and tongue, are showing a bluish color.
How old is your baby?
My baby is just 2 hours old.
Is the baby experiencing any difficulty with breathing or feeding?
He seems to be breathing a bit quickly.
Was the baby born at full term and were there any complications during delivery?
Yes, he was born at 39 weeks, and there were no complications during delivery.
Does your baby have any abnormalities in the shape of the chest or heart sounds?
His heart sounds seem to have only one sound instead of two, but there are no murmurs.
Does your family have a history of congenital heart disease?
I have had type 2 diabetes for 11 years.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Cyanotic Heart Disease, likely Transposition of the Great Arteries.

The baby was born at 39 weeks with no complications during delivery.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a bluish color on my body, including my lips and tongue.
How old is the patient experiencing these symptoms?
The patient is 2 hours old.
Is the baby experiencing any breathing difficulties or feeding problems?
The breathing rate is a bit high at 45 breaths per minute.
Was the baby born full-term, and were there any complications during delivery?
The baby was born at 39 weeks, which is full-term, and there were no complications mentioned during delivery.
What is the baby's current heart rate, and has a pulse oximetry test been performed?
The baby's heart rate is 150 beats per minute, and the oxygen saturation is 84% on room air.
Has the baby undergone any imaging studies like a chest X-ray or echocardiogram yet?
Yes, a chest X-ray has been done.
What were the findings of the chest X-ray?
I'm sorry, but as a patient, I wouldn't be able to interpret the results of the chest X-ray.
Understood. Are there any heart murmurs or abnormal heart sounds detected?
No murmurs were detected, just a single second heart sound.
Does the baby have any swelling or excess fluid in any part of the body?
There was no mention of swelling or excess fluid.
Does the baby have a family history of congenital heart diseases or any genetic disorders?
There's no mention of a family history of heart diseases or genetic disorders, just that the mother has had type 2 diabetes for 11 years.

Final Diagnosis: Congenital Cyanotic Heart Disease, likely Tetralogy of Fallot or another form of cyanotic congenital heart defect. Further investigation with an echocardiogram is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.
